docs.snippet: Tens of thousands of people celebrated in Rio de Janeiro after the Brazilian city beat Madrid, Tokyo and Chicago in the International Olympic Committee’s vote....
docs.lead_paragraph: When Rio de Janeiro was elected host city for the 2016 Olympic Games on Friday, the room where its bid team gathered turned into a boisterous party with members in uniform navy or moss green blazers hugging, dancing, crying and waving Brazilian flags. The bid leader, Carlos Arthur Nuzman, yelled, ''We did it! We did it!'' Rio and Chicago had gone into the day considered the favorites, ahead of Tokyo and Madrid. But by the time Rio was chosen by the International Olympic Committee to become the first South American city to host the Olympics, the Chicago delegation and its star-studded supporters were nowhere in sight.
docs.abstract: International Olympic Committee chooses Rio de Janeiro to be host city for 2016 Olympic Games; Rio will be first South American city to host Olympics; Rio and Chicago were considered favorites, ahead of Tokyo and Madrid, but despite support of Pres Obama--who flew in to address IOC voters--Chicago finished last; Chicago officials had worked nearly four years and spent nearly $50 million to bring Summer Olympics to US for first time since 1996 Atlanta Games; photos (M)

multimedia.caption: Chicago Loses 2016 Olympic Bid
multimedia.credit: Residents react to news that Chicago was the first city eliminated from final voting by the International Olympic Committee to host the 2016 Summer Olympics.

legacy.MultimediaSummary2: Residents react to news that Chicago was the first city eliminated from final voting by the International Olympic Committee to host the 2016 Summer Olympics.

multimedia.caption: One City Celebrates, Another Gasps
multimedia.credit: Rio de Janeiro and Chicago were considered the front-runners to host the 2016 Summer Olympics, but it was Rio’s bid that won.

headline.main: Rio de Janeiro Picked to Hold 2016 Olympics

byline.original: By JULIET MACUR; Monica Davey contributed reporting from Chicago; Alexei Barrionuevo from Rio de Janeiro; and Richard Sandomir, Katie Thomas and Lynn Zinser from New York

docs.snippet: Senator Barack Obama ''suspended'' his campaign and returned home to Chicago on Friday night for personal reasons: to celebrate the 16th anniversary of his marriage to Michelle.     ''You know what you guys could give us for our anniversary?'' Mr....
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama ''suspended'' his campaign and returned home to Chicago on Friday night for personal reasons: to celebrate the 16th anniversary of his marriage to Michelle. ''You know what you guys could give us for our anniversary?'' Mr. Obama told reporters aboard his campaign plane late Wednesday night, pleading for some ''quiet time.'' ''Not have a camera pool outside of the restaurant, so that everybody knows that we're there.''
docs.abstract: Sen Barack Obama suspends campaigning and returns home to Chicago to celebrate 16th anniversary of his marriage to Michelle; photo (M)

docs.snippet: Six small-business owners get special invitations to President Obama's jobs speech...
docs.lead_paragraph: Whenever a president addresses Congress, the White House invites a panel of Americans, distinguished and not, to watch the speech with the first lady from prime seats in the gallery above. The guests tend to be demographically diverse, but they also tend to be united in representing priorities the president intends to emphasize in the speech.
